#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk grub2
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: grub2 bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The grub2 packages provide version 2 of the Grand Unified Bootloader (GRUB), a highly configurable and customizable bootloader with modular architecture. It support a variety of kernel formats, file systems, computer architectures, and hardware devices. This update fixes the following bugs: Prior to this update, the basic bootloader configuration used alphabetical order for selecting the default boot entry. As a consequence, the kernel-debug boot entry was selected as default if it was included in the initial installation. With this update, the bootloader sorting algorithm has been improved and kernel-debug is no longer selected as the default boot entry. (BZ#1065360) The GRUB2 bootloader loads from the /boot/grub2/ directory, where the GRUB2 environment block data is stored on Linux systems. However, on UEFI systems, GRUB2 is not located in /boot/grub2/. Consequently, changes made to the GRUB2 environment block by GRUB2 utilities on a Linux system were previously not reflected when using GRUB2 to boot a UEFI system. This update creates a symbolic link between /boot/grub2/ and the location of GRUB2 on a UEFI system, which prevents the described problem. (BZ#1119943, BZ#1127071) Due to a missing check for the IBM pSeries QEMU machine, the cursor was in some cases not displayed when editing the kernel configuration during the boot of an IBM Power Systems architecture guest in graphics mode. The missing check has been added, and in the described scenario, the cursor is now visible as expected. (BZ#1080051) In addition, this update adds the following enhancements: Support for the little-endian variant of IBM Power Systems and the the 64-bit ARM architecture has been added to GRUB2, which allows users to build and run the grub2 packages on systems with these architectures. (BZ#967937, BZ#1125540) For increased clarity, the kernel names in the GRUB2 boot menu now also contain the corresponding release version number of Red Hat Enterprise Linux. (BZ#996794) Title matching has been added to the GRUB2 fallback variable. This allows users to specify fallback boot entries based on their titles, where it was previously only possible to specify the entries by their numbers. (BZ#1026084) The GRUB2 priority order when searching for the configuration path options during a netboot on IBM Power Systems has been adjusted to be more reliable and intuitive. The new order searches for a "grub.cfg-[OPTION]" file, where [OPTION] can be the following, in order of priority: the client Universally Unique Identifier (UUID), the client MAC address, and the client IP address. [OPTION] can be also be a part of the IP address, with priority increasing proportionally to the amount of characters from the IP address included. (BZ#1148652) The GRUB2 UEFI binary files have been enhanced to support regular expressions, which enables the use of regular expressions in GRUB2 configuration files on UEFI systems. (BZ#1125916) Users of grub2 are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
